problem: Let $P(x)$ be a nonzero polynomial such that $(x-1)P(x+1)=(x+2)P(x)$ for every real $x$, and $\left(P(2)\right)^2 = P(3)$. Find $P(\tfrac72).$
solution:
Setting $x = 1,$ we get
\[0 = 3P(1),\]so $P(x)$ has a factor of $x - 1.$

Setting $x = -2,$ we get
\[(-3) P(-1) = 0,\]so $P(x)$ has a factor of $x + 1.$

Setting $x = 0,$ we get
\[(-1) P(1) = 2P(0).\]Since $P(1) = 0,$ $P(0) = 0,$ which means $P(0)$ has a factor of $x.$

Let
\[P(x) = (x - 1)(x + 1)x Q(x).\]Then
\[(x - 1)x(x + 2)(x + 1) Q(x + 1) = (x + 2)(x - 1)(x + 1)x Q(x).\]This simplifies to $Q(x + 1) = Q(x).$

Then
\[Q(1) = Q(2) = Q(3) = Q(4) = \dotsb.\]Since $Q(x) = Q(1)$ for infinitely many values of $x,$ $Q(x)$ must be a constant polynomial.  Let $Q(x) = c,$ so
\[P(x) = c(x - 1)(x + 1)x.\]Then $P(2) = 6c$ and $P(3) = 24c,$ so
\[(6c)^2 = 24c.\]Solving, keeping in mind that $c \neq 0,$ we get $c = \frac{2}{3}.$  Then $P(x) = \frac{2}{3} (x - 1)(x + 1)x,$ and
\[P \left( \frac{7}{2} \right) = \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{5}{2} \cdot \frac{9}{2} \cdot \frac{7}{2} = \boxed{\frac{105}{4}}.\]
